awd_titl_txt: CAREER: High-Resolution Multidimensional Nonlinear Ion Mobility Spectrometry for Analytical Separations and Structural Characterization
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER award from the Chemical Measurement & Imaging Program (with co-funding from the Instrument Development for Biological Research Program) supports the efforts of Professor Alexandre Shvartsburg at Wichita State University to develop new technologies for the characterization of biomaterials.  Mass spectrometry (MS) is a technique used to identification and characterization biological and environmental samples.  To enable application to complex samples, MS is usually preceded by a separation step, typically employing solution-based methods of liquid chromatography or electrophoresis.  These methods are increasingly being replaced or complemented by much faster separations based on gas-phase ion mobility spectrometry (IMS), which can provide additional insight into elements of ion structure.  Dr. Shvartsburg and his group are advancing the capabilities of IMS based on fundamentally new measurement concepts.  The research is integrated with an educational program centered on an IMS exhibit in the Wichita Exploration Place and other science museums and discovery centers nationwide, and taken to schools as part of a K-12 outreach program.  The exhibit emulates IMS separations demonstrating the key aspects of resolution and sensitivity in an interactive format.  This effort is complemented by a summer program for faculty from undergraduate institutions and community colleges in Kansas, providing them with opportunities to learn more about MS, IMS, and their applications.  Incorporation of this knowledge into courses taught at their home institutions may help prepare students to contribute to a technology-based economy.

Initial IMS methods were designed such that measured ion velocities are linearly proportional to the applied electric field.  The relationship between field strength and velocity becomes more complex in strong fields, where ion mobility varies with field strength, enabling a newer technique called field asymmetric waveform IMS (FAIMS) that sorts ions by the difference between mobilities at high and low fields.  FAIMS is capable of providing exceptionally fine separations, extending, in favorable cases, to separations of isotopic isomers (isotopomers).  Dr. Shvartsburg is pursuing multiple approaches to advancing the resolving power of FAIMS by expanding the nonlinear IMS paradigm in fundamentally novel ways.  One approach is higher-order differential IMS employing more complex asymmetric waveforms to achieve unique separations.  Another is IMS with alignment of dipole direction, where the pendular locking of macromolecular dipoles permits capturing the directionally (rather than orientationally) averaged cross sections for more detailed structural characterization.  Implementation of FAIMS at reduced temperatures may extend the pendular regime to smaller ions (including essentially all peptides) and avoid heating ions above room temperature, which can cause dissociation or structural distortion in high-field IMS systems.  Assembly of multidimensional separations comprising linear and nonlinear IMS stages is central to this work.  By devising and sharing teaching tools related to these sophisticated concepts, Dr. Shvartsburg is not only advancing our characterization capabilities, but also helping prepare students with the skills and understanding needed to advance the state of technology.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
At the foundation of chemistry, the properties and functions of molecules are governed by structure. Hence, the major scientific breakthroughs came from the novel structure elucidation tools such as mass spectrometry (MS), spectroscopy, and NMR. An emerging paradigm to characterize the chemical structure is ion mobility spectrometry (IMS) based on the gas-phase transport of ionized molecules driven by electric field, which offers speed and unique specificity complementary to other methods. While IMS is known for a century, it was based on the absolute ion mobility at low electric fields. That has allowed separating and characterizing the structures of proteins, peptides, lipids, sugars, and other biomolecules central to life and health, but many species with similar geometries yet distinct biomedical roles (such as trans-fats versus normal cis-fats) remained unresolved. This limitation is addressed in a more recent approach of differential or field asymmetric waveform IMS (FAIMS) based on the difference between ion mobilities at high and low fields. Properly characterizing complex biological and environmental samples requires stacking multiple analytical steps. Hence, both traditional linear IMS and FAIMS are usually combined with MS and often further stages to identify the separated species.

This grant aimed to take the FAIMS technology and applications to the next level for FAIMS itself, its broader multidimensional integration, and thus established fundamentally new capabilities. The key metric of analytical separations is resolution, which for FAIMS scales as the electric field or waveform amplitude cubed. Our engineering upgrades have raised that amplitude to the physical limit of 7 kV, substantially increasing resolution across the gas compositions. High-resolution FAIMS stages have been attached to low-resolution MS platforms such as ion traps, severely constraining the utility of FAIMS/MS systems. We coupled high-resolution FAIMS to Orbitrap MS, overcoming the incompatibility of FAIMS buffers with ultrahigh vacuum in several ways. This has allowed separations of large biologically important modified peptide isoforms (including the histones, glycopeptides, and D-amino acid containing peptides) and lipids of various types comprising said trans-fats and isomers with alternative double bond positions.

Further enabled electron transfer and ozone-induced dissociation steps have permitted confident assignment of resolved species. The orthogonality of FAIMS and linear IMS allows yet more powerful 2-D FAIMS/IMS separations. We have implemented those at high resolution by combining high-definition FAIMS with high-resolution linear (trapped) IMS on the Bruker TIMS/ToF platform. These novel avenues for delineation and quantification of biomolecules would help us understand the crucial cellular processes and develop the biomarkers to diagnose or treat the associated health conditions.

The ubiquitous MS isotopic envelopes tell the molecular composition, but nothing about the structure. We discovered that the inter-isotopic shifts in FAIMS hinged on the ion geometry, thus distinguishing isomers. That was initially demonstrated for the isomeric halogenated aromatic compounds, including the consequential environmental contaminants and illicit drugs. That study has revealed the hallmark properties of isotopic shifts - additivity, qualitative dependence on the gas identity, and stability with minor waveform or gas composition variations permitting calibration-free assignments. The independent shifts for different substitutions, including the nominally isobaric isotopologues disentangled by Orbitrap MS, create exceptionally specific matrices operationally resembling the multidimensional NMR. We have started building the models to predict isotopic shifts depending on the label and ionic structure.

We conceptualized the third IMS methodology: low-field differential (LOD) IMS with the separations of macromolecules exploiting the alignment of strong permanent dipoles in a moderate field without significant ion heating. The field-dependent LODIMS parameters reveal the dipole moments and orientations within the molecular frame, which are unobtainable by other means and provide structural constraints complementary to regular IMS, H/D exchange, and other probes. Coupling to the Q-Exactive UHMR instrument (m/z limit of 80,000) has extended our FAIMS analyses to MDa protein complexes such as antibody oligomers. These new capabilities ought to become valuable tools for integrative structural biology.

We closely collaborate with industry to commercialize the technology for broad community benefit. The ambient-pressure FAIMS stages were disseminated to other researchers via a start-up Heartland MS with installations in the US and foreign academic, government, and industrial laboratories. Those produced multiple publications expanding FAIMS to nuclear forensics, chiral separations, and other new areas. I separately worked with Shimadzu to develop low-pressure FAIMS within the MS vacuum envelope, which accelerated the analyses by order of magnitude and allowed extreme fields up to 500 Townsend leading to unprecedented separations of macromolecules that survive at such fields because of intermittent heating and large kinetic delays.

Our work under this grant has resulted in 25 papers in peer-reviewed journals, including 16 in Analytical Chemistry - the top journal in the field. The findings were presented in 15 invited and 54 contributed conference talks and 38 invited seminars in 16 countries. This record illustrates the extent of global interest in our FAIMS technology development pursued at WSU with the continued NSF support.

 


Last Modified: 10/10/2023
Modified by: Alexandre Shvartsburg
